ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained historical, critical, and practical skills as they relate to ethnographic methods. I learned how to think about anthropology and ethnography in the long duree and was exposed to current examples of ethical and revelatory ethnographies.
Ethnography, theoretical frameworks, history of the anthropological field in relationship to Lain America.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Great syllabus! The three sections of the course was extremely helpful to better understand the development of the field. Hemispheric perspective helped understand global frameworks of ethnography Weaknesses: Sometime there was too much to discuss that we didn't get to every reading.
I wish students led the class, even for just 10 minutes, once a semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Professor Ramos-Zayas is one of the best professors at Yale and she truly cares about her subject and her students.
